May 22 2007 	Hotel Astoria - great value for the price	I was lucky enough to visit San Franscisco for a conference May 16 and 17. For two nights a friend and I stayed at the Marriott on 4th just south of Market - noted here to provide some perspective ;). Because we like to save our pennys for things other than expensive hotels, I did my research on this and other web sites, and settled on the Hotel Astoria for the remaining 3 nights. We were assigned a room on the 7th floor, facing away from the streets, so did not have significant amounts of street noise (I live a block off of an interstate freeway...). The breakfast was typical hotel continental breakfast fare - muffins, bagels or bread (from Costco?), coffee (drinkable, not great...) and OJ. Filling enough to get us up and out. Better than the food were the people - we met visitors from other areas of the US, Croatioa, Brazil, Netherlands, Belgium and other places. Positives: The room was relativaly quiet - altho I did hear a group of people walk down the hallway sometime in the middle of one night. The room was clean, the bathroom appeared to have been remodeled recently - new fixtures, shower stall, tile. The property was centrally located - easy access to the Muni, Bart, Cable Cars. We (two women) felt safe walking around the area of San Francisco the hotel was located in (we usually returned to our room around 10 pm each night). Breakfast was filling. We had a small table and chairs in the room, set in the corner, under the window (which opened too far for my liking - if I wwere traveling with small children). Negatives: The elevator is a bit scary... but did work to get us up to our 7th floor room. The view from our window was, well, there was no view... The TV reception was lousy (there seemed to be quite a few channels - I don't have cable - so my perspective may be skewed). There is a deadbolt on the room door - but the room key doesn't lock it... so the room is only secured with the door knob lock when you are out (the deadbolt and a chain can be used from inside the room). We were not after amenities - only a clean room with a private bath and two beds (twin beds). We did not plan to watch TV, so did not care about the bad reception. This is a great hotel to stay in if you plan to be out sightseeing most of your time in San Francisco. If you expect to be pampered, have amenities of any sort - perhaps you'd be happier some place else. I will definatly consider staying at the Hotel Astoria next time I go to San Francisco.

May 10 2007 	what I was looking for and then some	Ive been to San Francisco a dozen times as a tourist over a twelve year period (I really love it there), with my wife and on my own, and we/I stayed in twice as many different hotels. Places like the now closed Foleys, the beautiful Majestic, the only average King George, and the generic and overpriced Sheraton at Fishermans Wharf, to name just a few.As a budget minded traveler I am always after the best possible deal, which for me means a clean room with an equally clean private bath, in an accommodation that attracts civilized tourists and regular business travelers. It also has to be in a central and therefore convenient location for me as a foot passenger; in walking distance to shops, theatres and restaurants as well as public transportation.Even with this list of priorities the choice among hotels in San Francisco is almost overwhelming. Therefore I preferably narrow it down further by setting the rate limit to $100, tax included. And lets pack a (continental) breakfast on top for good measure. Surprisingly enough, you still have a handful of hotels to choose from.Two years back I picked the Cornell Hotel De France, which for $79 plus tax per night even had a warm breakfast in its downstairs restaurant included. But since I wasnt able to secure such an unbeatable deal this time around (too many good reviews to stay that cheap, I guess), I had to look elsewhere.In cities like New York or London for instance it would never cross my mind to consider hotels rated with just one star. San Francisco on the other hand is different even in this respect. In 1996 I stayed for a whole week in a one star property right in the middle of the infamous Tenderloin district on Ellis Street, and it was more than okay, in- and outside the building. Therefore a single star in the rating alone does not scare me away.I cant remember exactly how the Hotel Astoria got on my shortlist for 2007, but I know that Trip Advisor played a part. By then (Fall 2006) they had positive as well as some alarming reviews about it, so I still had to make up my mind. What finally convinced me was (a) the perfect location on Bush @ Grant, (b) their reassuringly down-to-earth homepage, and of course (c) the nightly rate of a mere $77 total for what they call their Deluxe Room. And yes, this does include not only a continental breakfast but also the tax.The Hotel Astoria matched my priorities in each point. It is a very basic accommodation, though; you have to keep that in mind. The one star rating is correctly applied. And there are a few minor drawbacks, like only 5 coat hangers (I stayed a week), no phonebook, no A/C, only a handful of TV channels available, none of them received without distortion, and sound-insulation-free windows, which secure the alarm-clock sparing sound of Bush Street from 5 AM on. But it was a great deal nevertheless. My room (# 404) was big enough, with a nice bathroom, a walkable closet and even a writing desk with chair and an additional armchair, and it was clean and well serviced. I slept exceptionally well on the firm mattress. The breakfast was fine with me, really. Far from being a feast, and the breakfast room is a bit depressing, but I had my preferred toasted bagels with cream cheese, coffee and an oj and was happily filled until noon. Also regarding the personnel I can only state that I was treated very welcoming and friendly by everyone I came across. Even more so, when I asked for assistance I experienced a service level that exceeded my expectations by far. Without going into detail, I was positively stunned!Did I enjoy my stay at the Hotel Astoria? Yes! Would I stay there again? You bet! Actually, I am about to make another reservation for next year. You know what favorable reviews do to the rates

Mar 17 2007	No better place to crash	The hotel has one of the best location with the best price. It is polarizing though, half will love it, the other will hate it. Here's why:Hate-it camp:The room is nothing but basic accomodation - nothing more than a basic mattress, a small TV, clean bathroom and that's it. it's noisy, being 2 blocks from union square does not help. Mar 11 2007 	Good value for the budget-minded traveler	Last time I was in San Francisco, I saw the Astoria and thought it looked like a decent-enough hotel. When I was called to the city on sudden business, I checked the Astoria's rates and found them to be astonishingly low for the hotel's location. I also checked Trip Advisor and saw mixed reviews. Based on what I read, I wasn't sure what to expect, but I decided to go ahead and stay at the Astoria -- I needed a cheap place to stay.Maybe it's because I didn't hold high hopes for the Astoria, but my stay there was a pleasant one. The hotel reminds me very much of places I've stayed in London -- small lift, narrow staircases.My room, which had an attached bath (I understand that some rooms do not have an ensuite, another similarity to small London hotels), was rather spartan (there is a television but no clock radio) but very clean. The very large window looked onto a small patio and could be opened widely for lots of fresh air. My room was very quiet too. While I could hear people pass in the hallway now and then, I did not hear guests talking in their rooms or watching television. It was peaceful.The bathroom was immaculate. In fact, I am hard-pressed to remember a cleaner hotel bathroom in my more recent travels. In terms of amenities, you will want to bring your own hair dryer, but the hotel does provide a shower cap, soap, and shampoo -- very basic toiletries on par with what you might find at a Red Roof Inn.The hotel's location is fantastic. The Montgomery BART station is two blocks away. Union Square and shopping heaven are two blocks down and one over. Chinatown is literally right outside the door. For people who want a bit more than the Astoria's continental breakfast, there is a Starbucks right across the street, another one a block down, and several pubs and cafes in between.Overall, my experience at the Astoria was great. It's clean and functional, and while it might not be the ideal setting for a romantic weekend getaway or a luxurious vacation, it's perfect for people who just need a convenient, clean, economical, well-situated place to crash. I will definitely be staying there again.

The elevator was scary. It lurched about. We usually took the stairs. The staff is very friendly. We'd stay there again. There wasn't any air conditioning when we stayed there, so if it's very hot, I'd check with staff before booking. We were fine with open windows. The view of the city is also nice.

You need to get milk and bread warm by yourself using the kitchen stuff available (microowen and toaster). No help by the staff but not a big deal.And someone here at TripAdvisor made complains about the towels. Yes, they are terrible, old and synthetic. And never dries. Oh, and the elevator is old too, it can only carry 3 people per trip, but it works (scary, but works). Anyway, I can say I stayed in places worst than this. There are plenty of options for dining and lunch around and public transport few blocks away. Very hard to find a good restaurant in Chinatown though. Nov 25 2009 	location location location	We stayed here for 5 nights. Overall I was impressed enough to reccomend this hotel in terms of location and value for money. It is a simple, no frills property located in an older style building. Check in staff were efficent, room was quite small but again, met our needs.The real selling point is location. Turn left at the hotel entrance and It is steps away from Chinatown gate which if you walk through will lead you through this area, down Columbus (Italian Quarter) and eventually down to Fisherman's Wharf. (approx 30min walk) Turn right instead and you are 5 min walk from Cable Car turnaround, 10 min walk to Market street, Union Square and the BART station (cheap and easy way of getting to and from the airport)The hotel is for the budget aware among us. If price of accomodation is not an issue then choose somewhere else but in a similar location. However, if like me you treat your room as little more than a crash pad and somewhere to freshen up between siteseeing and dinner then this hotel will suit your needs well.San Francisco is a very walkable city and the public transport links are pretty decent. In this respect, I would highly reccomend staying in this area as opposed to down at the Wharf where, it is more touristy. It is truely a beautiful city. Some highlights include: cable car to lombard st... hop off... walk down and up to Coit Tower... beautiful viewsbike the bridge but continue on into Sausalito... explore this lovely bayside community with art gallaries and cafe culture before you and your bike catch the ferry back to the Wharf.... beats cycling back!.. P.S. biking the bridge is a tougher ride than they let on.Go do Napa for the day... Take the nighttime Alcatraz tour instead of the daytime... far superior and atmospheric as dusk and then dark settles while you are out on 'the rock'You will love SF and if you are ok with no frills accomodation then you will love the Baldwin

My partner and I stayed at The Baldwin for 2 nights which we booked after reading good reviews on here.The room was plenty big enough for our needs and we were overlooking a street which was nice. The bathroom was fairly small but everything in looked new and it was clean as was the room itself.The staff we dealt with were all very helpful and friendly, allowing us to check in early on arrival and we asked them to recommend a chinese restaurant which they did (probably a relative!) and it was fabulous.The location is ideal - minutes walk from Chinatown and Union Square.The price was also great - far cheaper than staying at Fishermans Wharf.The only (slight) problem we had was with parking - upon arrival we were asked if we needed parking and said yes. They gave us a card and told us it was down the block and first left (Sutter Street) so off we went. When we checked out 2 days later, we found we had gone to the wrong car park (there must be 2 on Sutter Street and the one the hotel use is the second one) - this wasn't a problem for us as we hadn't moved the car but beware if you plan to drive anywhere and make sure you find the right car park as the one were in is charged by the hour. By not moving our car it cost us about $2 less than the hotel were charging for 'their' car park but I'm sure parking in theirs would allow you to take your car in and out for the one standard price (about $25 per day). We had to then go back to the hotel, explain what had happened and were given a refund for their car park (maybe they need to explain in more detail where their car park is in future as we were told we weren't the first to make the mistake but it they are clearly losing revenue by doing this)

Apr 22 2009 	You Get What You Pay For	I will preface this review by saying that I was looking for the most inexpensive way to stay in a major American city- San Francisco. In this one particular case, after having may successful trips with the advise of Trip Advisor, I was let down by the reviews on The Baldwin Hotel in San Francisco. Suffice it to say, this experience was mostly my own fault in the making. I have learned that indeed, you "get what you pay for"- especially in a large city such as San Fran.Positives: The Baldwin was one of the most inexpensive locales that I found in San Fran. The staff was very friendly and tried to be as accomodating as possible. The rooms were clean- if a bit spare.Negatives: Probably one of the worst nights I have spent in a hotel. The room was located on the 7th floor accessable by a small elevator (which had been mentioned in a previous review). I arrived in San Francisco in the middle of a "heat wave" (which is rare from what the locals tell me) with temps in the 90's. 1) The room had no air conditioning and has only a small water-radiator for heat- which was NOT needed!! The only relief was to open a window (without insect screens) and an overhead fan. As mentioned previously, the room was small. No rooms with King/Queen beds were available, so had two twin beds. 2) The advertised Wifi available is through a company located in -- Oregon-- the Wifi was sporadic at best, with the signal being lost constantly- also a charge of appox. $20 for three days use. 3) Water pressure in the shower/tube was dribbling (very weak) with little hot water available at around 7:30 AM.  3) The noise was the most agonizing factor of my entire one night's stay. My room, on the 7th floor, was located on the side of the building facing an alley-way- the only view was of the building next door (again mentioned in a previous review of this property). All During the night, traffic noise was terrible with the "back-up beeping" of serivce vehicles throughout the night- at one point, when trying to go to sleep apox. 10:30 PM there was about 10 minutes of glass breaking and beeping and the noise of a dumpster truck dumping several containers in the alley- imagine listening to this through an open window. I stayed for one night- I had made the reservations pre-paid through one of the major travel internet sites and, after talking with two hotel clerks and two representatives of this major travel site, I was refused even a partial refund for my booked 4 nights stay- the major travel site did give a $50 certificate for future use as an attempt for an apology.So, the moral of this story is: if you are trying to do your travel "on the cheap"- beware- even with good to moderate reviews on Trip Advisor- one paradise is another person's misery.

Mar 7 2009 	Would definitely stay here again	My partner and I stayed at the Baldwin for 5 nights in April 2008. We arrived quite late (as our flight from Australia arrived around 9pm), we didnt make it into the city until around 1030ish, but we were met with a warm and thankfully very swift reception. The hotel has a very cosy feel to it, more of a boutique feel, than a hotel (which i preferred). There were rows of SF information in the lobby and also hot coffee and tea available all night. The room was comfy with a large closet area, safe, tv, nice big comfy bed and a bathroom that was clean and practical (there was hardly any water pressure in the shower), but apart from that it was in a good location, near china town, near public transport, walking distance to the city centre (from memory around 10-15minutes) and secure (they would lock the door after a certain time at night and you need a key to get inside the hotel). they also helped arrange transfers to SFO when we departed. the whole hotel and room were instantly welcoming and i felt right at home as soon as i walked in the door. i would definitely recommend this hotel for anyone looking for a great deal in a cosy little boutique hotel. would suggest a lower level floor (to try and avoid using lifts), and would recommend requesting a room not directly facing the main road the hotel is located on. It can get a little noisy during the day, alot of foot traffic (although arriving into USA for the first time, i enjoyed watching people from my window and listening to the new noises).

Mar 6 2009 	Adequate	Arrived at 3.00 pm-met at reception by a pimply youth with a hickey on his neck-would not under any circumstances let me check in as the "official" check in time 4pm.Had to cool my heels at the Starbucks close by.Room was small,very clean and the water in the bathroom was luke warm at best.Called downstairs and the desk clerk arrived shortly thereafter to check it out.Made some adjustmenst downstairs to the boiler and lo and behold hot water returned.Best thing about this hotel as many pointed out is the location-just a few blocks from Powell street cablecar and BART.Lots of buses running in Stockton Str which will get you to North Beach etc- BTW for all you deli fans out there-do NOT miss going to Molinari's deli (323 Columbus Str) in North Beach-yummy sandwiches-dont go on Sunday though-surprisingly its closed-I guess the money is no longer important to them.Anyway I digress-in short the Baldwin is an adequate hotel and I would consider staying there again-paid USD85 for the night-which is pretty decent value.Fiirst time in San Francisco which I really enjoyed-Fishermans Wharf is a tourist trap of course-but lots to do and see.

Feb 15 2009 	Solid 2 star hotel	I left the Baldwin after a four night stay with mixed feelings. The hotel reminds me of the better B & B hotels one might find in London or Paris. Jan 9 2009 	Great Location !	My husband and I stayed at Hotel Baldwin from Dec 27 - 31, 2008. For its price of $82+/night, it was not a bad choice - room was basic but adequate. Sep 5 2008 	Stayed here Oct 2007. Good hotel Excellent Location	After what felt like months of trawling the pages of trip advisor, we finally decided on the Baldwin Hotel as it fitted in with our requirements of budget and location and had good reviews by fellow trip advisor members.The Baldwin is more than central, right at the gates of China Town and just a few blocks from Union Square. We originally booked a double room and then decided to upgrade to a queen. However, when we were shown the room the bed looked awfully small, like a 3/4 size, but when we checked with reception we were assured that it was in fact a queen size room. (I think this may be a language barrier between Americans and Brits so do check before booking, I think perhaps the double could have been a twin!!) Anyway, the room was in no way a problem. The bed was small, but cosy (boyfriend is 6ft 4); the room and bathroom were cleaned every day (left a 2 dollar tip every day). The sheets were clean and towels were fluffy and plentiful. The bathroom was lovely with a traditional cast iron bath with plenty of hot water and an EXCELLENT shower (I have a thing about hotel showers!!) all in all we were very happy and comfortable. On the down side (there isn't much), the decor is a little dated, but you're not in San Francisco to see hotel decor. There are NO tea/coffee making facilities in the room, so bring a travel kettle and supplies. The hotel advertises tea/coffee facilities in the lobby, however every time my boyfriend went for a coffee, there wasn't any, or worse it was always cold. Did not see any tea for the entire stay. The only other negative thing was the lack of air conditioning. Now coming from good old UK, we don't know the modern phenomenon of air conditioning, but I imagine that this could be a problem for some people. We were at the Baldwin in the last week of October 2007 and there was a bit of a heat wave. Temperatures were between 79 to 84F (26-28C) degrees everyday. We had the window open by day, but it gets very noisy outside due to the hotel's central location. It wasn't a problem for us, but I wouldn't advise staying here at the height of summer unless the hotel gets some air con. The staff greeted us very warmly and remained this way for the rest of the week, directing us to the post office, advising on trips, ordering cabs etcOur stay was room only so we had to forage for food everyday, but you will never go hungry or bored of food in San Francisco. We had sushi, Chinese, Italian, fish and so on and so on. Here are some of my favourite places to eat. 1. Cheesecake Factory top floor of Macy's. Very popular and touristy but well worth it.2. North Beach Restaurant in Little Italy. So delicious, the best pasta outside of Rome. Quite expensive, but worth a treat. Brilliant traditional fine dining3. Capps Corner. Americanised version of Italian cuisine. Generous portions, cheap and very very cheerful.4. Mayflower Market. This is a little deli/mini-market on Bush street between Stockton Street and Grant Avenue (around the corner from the hotel) You can get all sorts here, fruit, bagels, sandwiches, crisps etc All to help you have that cheap breakfast/lunch.San Francisco is the most amazing city and there is so much to see and do. Highlights of the week were the visit to Alcatraz (pre-book online before you go) Golden Gate Bridge, Japanese Tea Gardens, San Francisco Zoo, Haight-Ashbury District, Pier 39, and Muir Woods. Although you'll find the most amazing and interesting things around every corner.If you haven't worked it out by now, I simply LOVE San Francisco and sincerely hope that I will go back one day. I hope that you will love it just as much as me!! Please Enjoy:-)

Jun 30 2008 	Great hotel in SF	The Baldwin Hotel is an excellent choice of lodging in San Francisco. We could see the gate to ChinaTown from our window. You can walk anywhere from this location. Jun 28 2008 	Great value great location	My wife and I just stayed in the Baldwin Hotel for five nights and we enjoyed a very pleasant stay. We booked through an online service, pre-paid and took BART from San Francisco Airport, with a subway stop three blocks from the Baldwin. Check-in was quick and easy. Our room was on the 10th floor, with a queen-size bed and private bath. The room was small but very clean and the maid service every day was thorough. There were only two pillows on the bed but when we asked for two more they happily complied. I have read some complaints about the front desk but that was not our experience at all; they were always very friendly and helpful. The first night we stayed there it was hot but a ceiling fan kept it pretty comfortable. After that the temp. dropped and it was very comfortable. The elevator is slow but not so much as to be a problem. The location is excellent, right down the block from Chinatown; just beyond Chinatown is North Beach (a little Italy) and a bit farther Coit Tower (with another slow elevator that is worth the $5 charge to the top, where there are spectacular views). Union Square is also near, as is the cable car terminus down to Fisherman's Wharf. Trips to Alacatraz leave from Pier 33 but make a reservation - those trips fill up fast in the summer. The cable car trip is fun but there are long waits at the turn-arounds. We also took BART to the F line trolley to Fisherman's Wharf, which also worked well. There's also a Starbucks just up the block from the Baldwin. Checkout is at 11 a.m. and our plane did not leave until 5 p.m. However, they let us leave our bags at the front desk and we wandered around Chinatown for a few more hours. One depressing note: there are a lot of homeless in the general area, though we did not see any congregating at the Baldwin. Some are pretty aggressive demanding money though overall it is more than anything else a very sad testiment to our society's inability to make these folks' lives better than sleeping on the streets and begging.

Jun 21 2008 	Basic Hotel but Great Location	The Baldwin should really get a "3" rating, however the location and comparisons to other SF hotels for the price gives it the extra edge. Make no mistake, this is an old-style, bare bones hotel with no extra amenities. No AC, a creaky, slow old elevator, and very sloooow front desk sevice. However management has made the best of what it has, and the room I had smelled of fresh paint and the bathroom was newly redone, with immaculately white grout, new tiles and fixtures, and an effort to give a sense of a nice stay with decent toiletries.There is no AC, but a large ceiling fan that did its job on a spring evening. The front desk is usually manned by one, maybe two people who do not like to multi-task. Many Europeans seem to stay here, and the language barrier, as well as the ridiculous amount of paperwork upon check-in, as well as an antiquated computer system and the use of old fashioned metal keys leads to a lengthy wait should you be in line. Check in and check out take over 15 minutes-- There is decent free coffee in the lobby 24 hours a day, which is a nice touch. The beds have a lot to be desired, and the pillows are synthetic and flat. Only two pillows on a queen bed instead of four, and a cheap, thin cover with no extra blanket in the closet. On the plus side, there is a large safe in the closet to hold laptops and large personal items, and when you leave your room you can use the deadbolt lock in addition to the handle lock. Also, the hotel locks the front door between the hours of 10pm and 6am to keep non-guests out, and guests can enter with a key. The front desk always had someone there at late and early hours, for added security.The location cannot be beat. Turn in any direction from the front door and Union Square is all around you with its many restaurants and shops. The gate to Chinatown is right there as well. Close to the financial district too.There are many boutique hotels in SF, and you never quite know what you are getting yourself into, especially in the lower price ranges. With the Baldwin, it pretty much meets average expectations, with no negative surprises, and even a few positive ones, like how clean it is, good security, and the overall feeling that at least an effort is being made to make the best of what they have. The neighborhood is great and vibrant, and again, with Union Square, some of it can turn shady fast. Not so with this location. In all, I would stay here again if my more favored (luxury) hotels are seasonally priced out of my range. This is a great choice for a good value in an excellent setting.

Nov 14 2006 	Great Find	My husband and I had an excellent stay at the Baldwin Hotel (Oct 21-26). The staff were very friendly even at 11 pm when we checked in. The room was large with a spacious walk in closet. The bathroom was spotless and looked new. The room was thoroughly cleaned everyday and we had no complains whatsoever. There was fresh coffee in the foyer everyday......way better than Starbucks a few doors away. The hotel is close to Chinatown and other cafe's, restaurants and to main sights.We highly recommend this to all travellers to San Fran. With regards to the saxophone player.....his repertoire wasn't great but it was very nice having music drifting up into your room after a very long day of sightseeing........seemed like the real deal.Overall...great , would love to go back again

Nov 7 2006 	Great Location Great Price	We were amazed how centrally located this hotel was, for the cheap price per night. We would suggest getting a room with the gigantic clawfoot tub, perfect for soaking worn out legs from walking up and down the hills! The room itself was in need of a fresh coat of paint, etc., but for the price you can't get a better location. It's wonderful to be able to step out the front door and see the gate to Chinatown and the best shopping in town! Not to mention how close you are to the public transit and cable cars! You're never too far from great food, Chinatown's dim sum is excellent and there's tons of continental and "fancy" restaurants just down the block. The staff was very courteous and willing to help with anything. Do be cautious of the room door locks, we're not sure what happened but it seems like the door keys open more doors than just your door, but we're not certain. Overall a great place to stay!

Oct 29 2006 	A big up for Baldwin!	I'm so glad we took a look at this tripadvisor site before we made reservations because like the others below we are completely satisfied with Baldwin Hotel.We took a room w/ two doublebeds and it had a walk-in-closet and a very clean bathroom w/ a spacious bathtub.No view what so ever but that didn't matter since we were seldom in our room. The location was fab! Close to everything, cable cars, attractions, shops...you name it. Very friendly staff as well.The only thing that was annoying - and the hotel had no part in that -was a saxophone player that unfortunately had his spot right under our window and who played the same tune over and over again...aaargh.But apart from that we sincerely recommend this hotel to everyone who travels on a reasonably low budget.

Oct 18 2006	What a great hotel!!	The best deal in San Francisco. Excellent hotel, nice price, great location, clean and pleasant rooms, kind staff, prime location, safe area. I checked other hotels I had seen advertised for the same price, and the Baldwin is truly much better.

Oct 16 2006 	Charming central hotel	The most comfortable bed we had in our six week trip. An unbelivable location right outside the Chinatown gates and near Union Square and the cable car line. We wish we could have stayed for longer than our 2 night stay.

Sep 18 2006 	Run down hotel in a great location	This hotel was in a great location . It is minutes from Union Square and china town and only 15 mins walk from fishermans wharf.and its a nice walk too.The hotel itself is run down and in need of new carpets etc.. our bed was not a full double so I was disappointed. When I asked to move to a room with a larger bed they said they had nothing available! It can be noisy and I did hear the elevator from both rooms.only slightly but there is no getting away from it. However I suppose its a case of you get what you pay for. In relation to other hotels it is cheap and if you want to spend your money on the attractions its ideal. I found the staff ok but nothing special. Not a bad hotel in a wonderful city

Sep 3 2006	Great Little Hotel In The Center Of Everything	I was extremely pleased with this hotel! The staff were very nice and helpful! Aug 29 2006	Great for the price!	The Baldwin is a 1940's hotel just below the Chinatown Gate. Good location for shopping and getting anywhere on mass transit. Get the Tourist Pass and go crazy. The rooms are good size, very clean and reasonably quiet (stay away from the elevator!). No breakfast, but places to eat are nearby and abundant. The staff was friendly and very helpful when needed. No clock in room and crap TV, but really not issues for me. Good value.

Aug 18 2006 	A Pleasant Stay	We stayed there four nights. The room was simple and smaller than chain hotels but if you're there to see the city and not the room than it's not a problem. The room was very clean and in good condition with the exception of the carpeting which needed to be replaced. No noise from other rooms and we weren't near the elevator so no comment there. I must say the staff at the front desk was very friendly and helpful in their suggestions of places to go. Overall, for what we paid for the room, we were pleased. Oh, and the best part - the location! Chinatown is right there. North Beach, Union Square, BART, and cable cars are all within walking distance. We would stay here again.

Jul 31 2006	Good bargain	After I booked it, I learned Hotwire rates the Baldwin as a one-star hotel. That made me apprehensive, but my stay in late July effectively erased that. Hotwire's rankings are based, in part, on a hotel's amenities. By that standard, it's true that the Baldwin is far from luxury. The rooms don't have refrigerators, hair dryers, safes, coffee makers, air conditioning and the TV doesn't have a movie option. There's no restaurant on the premises and no room service or nightly turn-down service. No swimming pool, either.While these are all fine features to have, they do affect the room price. Not having them also affects the room price -- in this case making the Baldwin a bargain in expensive downtown San Francisco.Here's what my room did have:Lots of space and absolute cleanliness. Hotel-average furniture. Two very comfortable beds with good mattresses. New windows that effectively kept out street noise. Thick wall construction -- no sound transmission from other rooms. A ceiling fan. Cable TV. Usual shampoo/soap. Lots of good-quality towels. Bathroom that looked as if it had been recently modernized with new tile floor. General look of good maintenance -- no chipped paint or dirty walls or windows. In the lobby there's free a.m. coffee and tea. You can borrow a hair dryer. There's a public internet computer (pay extra to use it). There's also parking at a garage around the corner (think the hotel's Web site has info about that). The staff was helpful and courteous.This hotel is in a safe area just steps from Chinatown and the Financial District, making it extremely well located for business or vacation travel. There's a Starbucks in the same block, a Japanese restaurant next door, a cafe across the street, a convenience store around the corner and more Chinese restaurants than you can count within about three blocks. In recent years I've stayed in half a dozen of San Francisco's small boutique hotels (and one large one -- the Marriott, which was filthy). While I can't say the Baldwin is my absolute favorite (I do like an in-room fridge), it truthfully is as nice or nicer than others that cost more.I'd stay there again in an instant.

Jul 27 2006 	Great Price Great Location Great Hotel	The Baldwin Hotel is located about half a block away from the gates of Chinatown. I was able to look outside the window and see the gates of Chinatown--wonderful view. I got a twin size bed room. The room is decent size. Each room has its own bathroom (HUGE PLUS for a budget hotel). One strange thing was there was no mirror above the sink in the bathroom. I found shaving a bit awkward. The mirror was located behind (not on the same side as the sink but opposite). Old style claw feet bathtub w/ shower. I will definitely stay here. It is also a 5-minute walk to the financial district. If you are on a budget, then this hotel is a fantastic place to stay.

Jun 25 2006	Excellent deal	We stayed at the Baldwin Hotel for over a week, and was amased by the place when comparing it with what we paid for a hotel at such a convenient location.The rooms were clean and they had a very helpful staff.I do not understand those who complain about small rooms or noisy elevator.The location is excellent just a block from Union Square.Starbucks and other places to have breakfast just outside the main entranceIf we were to return to SF, we would use this Hotel again.

Jun 5 2006	Great Deal!!	I would stay at the Baldwin again in a heartbeat if I were to return to San Fran. The rooms were basic and a little small but VERY clean. The bathrooms are large and there is a walk-in closet for great storage. The hotel is in a great, safe location. I stayed with 3 other girls in our mid-twenties and I never felt unsafe. The hotel is close to the Powell and Montgomery stop on the BART and in the middle of the high-end shopping district. It is about a block from Union Square and about 50 yards from the entrance of Chinatown. If you are looking for an affordable place to stay so that you can spend your money on sightseeing and shopping the Baldwin is for you!

May 23 2006	Perfect for the price	Honestly, I didn't expect much when my husband and I was going to SF. We know it's an expensive city, and USD 90 for two nights sounds a little too good to be true. May 17 2006 	Good place to stay	We stayed at this hotel for 5 days (22 - 28 Apr 2006). The staff was friendly and helpful. The price was just right. Just 10 min walk to Montgomery or Powell St. The room is very basic.
